The deserts were phenomenal. Thank you Kelly, Ozzy and Seasons 52 for an amazing evening. We will be back for the next girls night!

One of my favorite places when I am craving a light but satisfying meal. I have had scallops here several times and I have always been very pleased. I have also really loved their flat breads! Yum! Need to go there again soon. For those of you not from Chicago, this is a great place to eat while shopping the mag mile. Have fun!

For the price (not inexpensive), I found the food fairly bland and uninspired. This is a good place for a group who wants a "little of everything" - as they have everything from sushi to flatbreads to meat main courses, but as a result of the giant menu, I felt they didn't really hone in and excel at any one category of items.  But the cardinal sin? An old fashioned made with soda water. Just not ok at the prices they are charging. They need real mixologists who have a love of cocktails behind the bar, and a corporate plan that supports real cocktails. Overall, just an ok meal. I wouldn't return as it is now. There are just too many other good restaurants to experience in Chicago.
Generic tasting food, bit charges upscale prices.  Pass.  Eddie V's across street is better.

How happy I was when they finally brought delicious establishment to the Downtown Chicago area! Seasons 52 represents everything that is fresh and savory. Their menu changes by the season (hence the name) and your taste buds dance along to the live music that they have nightly. *angels singing* My friend and I started off our dinner the right way - with wine flights. BOOZE!!! I had the white wine flight that consisted of a Rose, a Pinot and a Riesling. Deslish! I also decided to try their Port wine, which was a 10 year aged Tawny Port. Totally savory! The red wine flight that my friend had was awesome as well and the best thing about it? You get a full glass of whichever wine was your favorite. Didnt like any in the flight? They'll almost for certain give you a glass of whatever you prefer. BOOZE! For dinner, I chose the Shrimp Cavatappi Pasta. Im not a huge fan of veggies, but this dish consisted of roasted tomatoes, mushrooms, broccolini and peppers and  I almost bit my fingers off devouring this dish. You can definitely tell that everything is fresh and in-season - from the shrimp to the veggies. Im sure that they have their own personal shrimp-swimmer-catcher'er!! The Salmon that my friend had was roasted on a cedar plank and was cooked to perfection. I couldve totally been a beaver and ate the wood plank that it was cooked on (Okay I know Beavers dont EAT wood) Dont judge me.  If I had of had room for desert, Im sure it wouldve been a scrumptious as everything else.  Seasons 52 is a definite go to for a semi-upscale, relaxing, dining experience. Be sure to check them out after work for their special of your choice of wine flight plus a flat bread pizza for around $15!

This was our second time at this location and it was actually better than the first! That was all due to our server, KELLY, who was the sweetest, most accommodating and helpful server we've had in a long time! Thanks to Kelly's guidance, the chef and kitchen made me a beautiful dinner of steamed veggies and potatoes....because I'm completely plant based! The bonus was listening to Zoey play 'Somewhere Over the Rainbow" which happens to be my favorite song!!  Thank you Seasons 52, and KELLY....we'll definitely be back.
Good food, good service and nice environment.  Not exactly a unique choice when you're in a city like Chicago but I appreciate that you get consistency from one Seasons 52 location to the next.

Very impressed! Visited for lunch with a Gilt City deal after a friend said how much they had enjoyed their 'flatbreads and flights'. The butternut squash soup was perfect. Also tried the salmon and scallops with risotto. Highly recommended, especially since the food is so fresh and thoughtfully prepared. Extra thanks to our server Moni for being so helpful and happy!

My scallop risotto was pretty good. Surprisingly it was only 500 calories! Tasted great and was healthy My Brussel sprouts were Overcooked so I sent it back and they recooked it. It was better but still not to my liking. In the end they took it off my bill

Love this place! Not only was the food incredible and filling, everything is under 400 calls! The service is worth mentioning. My friend and I went in mid-late afternoon on labor day. We had an exhausting day and were starving! We ordered quickly and it seemed like our food was taking just a little bit too long, not long enough for us to say anything to our waiter, but a few minutes longer than you would think. Once we got it we had forgotten all about the wait and enjoyed the filling meal. When the bill came the waitress informed us she took off our app's and even our first round of drinks for the wait. Can't beat that! Can't wait to go back again.

I went there with my husband for a date. We had flat bread salmon desert and few drinks. We loved the service restaurant`s atmosphere. Dessert is the point!!! Definitely absolutely going there again :) Plus they have lower calorie food.

I ordered the crispy ban mih sandwich, and it is definitely a 5 star. The layers of flavors and the crispyness of the wrap mixed together so well. The sweetness of the duck, the spicy sauce, and the pickled raddish match each other so well. Service is good too.

Came here for lunch while traveling for work. Wow - what a great place! First, I love that they put such an emphasis on creating healthy food. Everything on their lunch menu is under 475 calories which I genuinely appreciate, especially when traveling for work and eating out all of the time. The best part is that the food doesn't taste like diet food! I ordered the fish tacos which were delicious and I highly recommend them. I also added Seasonal Corn on the side (minus the bacon) and oh my gosh, how yummy! The corn was still had some of those silk hairs in it which tells me that they used fresh corn on the cob to create this side dish! I was glad they cut the corn off of the cob because while there is a time and a place to eat corn on the cob, a work lunch is not one of those times. My colleague also enjoyed his entree. This is a wonderful restaurant - I highly recommend it!

Making the reservations was simple, and the website was easy to navigate. You could find the menu, wines, and address easily. As we were driving to the restaurant, which is located on Grand and Rush, we did not see the valet. We went to a public parking place and ended up paying $27 instead of the $14 for valet, but no one was outside when we drove by so we just assumed there was no valet. As we were walking to the restaurant from the parking building we really could not see their signs, a recommendation would be to enlarge the signs so you could see them clearly across the street.    When we entered the restaurant there were three hosts who welcomed us and asked if we had a reservation. As we were led to our seats, beautiful music filled my ears. A man behind the bar sat behind his piano. His fingers danced to the melody they were creating while he sang. The ambiance was just beautiful in the restaurant. It was all a stone and dark wood theme. It was enchanting. When she was seating us she did make casual 'weather' conversation to the table, complemented me on my dress, and pulled out a chair for me. She did not mention the server's name when seating us. It took the server around 7 minutes to come and acknowledge us. He did ask if this was our first time which was nice and explained the Seasons 52 theme and how they change their menu. He also mentioned the desserts because they are known for their presentation of desserts. There uniform was a bit odd because it was just plain black pants and a black t-shirt, it seemed too casual for me.   Taking the order he asked about cocktails first, but we did not get any. He then he asked about other drinks like beer, wine, or teas. Since I am not 21, I did not order alcohol but the person I was with did order a Cabernet Savion, which he said was one of the best he has ever tried. The server did not ask about allergies or dietary restrictions before taking our order, which could pose as a health hazard to customers. When it came to the appetizer he suggested a few and we went with the Tandoori-Style Grilled Chicken Skewers tropical chutney, cucumber raita, which was very flavorful and delicious. He checked back on us within the 2 minutes/2 bits rule. Then once we were done we ordered the entrees and I ordered the Oak-Grilled Filet Mignon with cremini mushrooms, steamed leaf spinach, mashed potatoes, red wine sauce, but I did not want the mushrooms so he suggested brocolini. I was not sure what it was and he explained it as longer broccoli like vegetables. The other person I went with ordered the Oak-Grilled Rack of Lamb spring vegetables, yukon Gold mashed potatoes, and shallot jus. This took about 17 minutes to cook and bring to the table that was brought by a food runner I am assuming. He almost forgot to bring out steak knives before the meal. The meal was delicious and and everything was cooked to perfection pretty much, well at least the way we asked. When we had polished off our meal, the waiter returned he was sure we were finished, but he did not take the dishes to our right. He only cleared the dishes in front of us.   When it came to desserts a different waiter presented the desserts to us because he has a party of 15 he was taking care of at the moment. They severed mini indulgences, which were just a longer shot glass filled with the cake, filling, or cream based dessert. We ordered the Mocha Macchiato and the Belgian Chocolate S'more. The sweet flavors filled my mouth upon contact with my taste buds. The server never came and refilled my water and did not check up on us during dessert. When the check was brought he charged us for 5 extra desserts we did not order so we had to wait around for that.

Had dinner here on a Friday night.  The place was just about empty. The service was good, the food was just okay.  The interior was a bit too dark. The music coming from the piano player was forgettable...not good, not bad, just there.  The decor was just a bit bland, very corporate, and you could tell it was a chain.  I would recommend redesigning the interior to make it more fun and lively.  Also, I would change up the music. It was too quiet and not uplifting.

This is my second seasons 52 restaurant. The first was in Kansas City. This is a restaurant that travels well. Both were excellent and I had a piece of salmon tonight that was just perfect. Very attentive servers

Perfect.  I really wish I took my parents here instead of the Signature Room in the Hancock. Here's why: Patrick, our server, was very well trained, very thorough, and service was top-notch. I especially love servers that go the extra mile and tell you their favorites, explain the dish concept, and find moments to check up on you when you're not busy awkwardly stuffing your face.  Chris, the live entertainment, took song requests and saw that I loved Blackbird and played my favorite Beatles album in order while the restaurant was winding down until we left. Great ambiance, and great dining experience.  The food was excellent. Surprising that each dish has great portions and is still under 500 Cal. We ordered 2 flights of wine and flatbread, the Lamb, and a few cocktails. The Strawberry Coconut Martini was exceptional.

This Seasons 52 in River North was a great place for a recent work dinner I planned for 12 people. Having been to Seasons in Schaumburg, I knew their  organic and locally sourced food would be a hit, and the quiet ambiance of a private room was perfect for us.  It was easy to book for a private party, I just had to fill out an online form and return a PDF to show intent to save the date. This location's dining layout isn't quite as expansive as the Schaumburg location, but you'll find warm wood toned booths and tables, and this location is near the heart of River North shopping and dining.   For group dining Seasons 52 has a few different Prix Fixe choices, and I went with the Pinot Noir menu. The menu gave us lots of options, but we all ate: Flatbreads- Roasted Roma Tomato, and Grilled Garlic Chicken Pesto were both great Salad- Crisp Romaine and Kale Caesar, a great take on a Caesar Then we got to choose between: Herb-Roasted Chicken, Wood-Roasted Pork Tenderloin, Cedar Plank Roasted Salmon  I chose the salmon, which came with a nice side of roasted potatoes and carrots. The salmon was excellent and it was a popular choice among our group.  Service was very good- they constantly checked in to see if the room temp was good, if we wanted music piped into the room, and recommended great wine pairings. The only tip I would add for groups is to introduce the restaurant's unique mission to the group, and also explain what would be brought out family style, and what the diners could choose for themselves. Otherwise, service was great all night, and I wouldn't hesitate to bring a group here again, or stop in if I was shopping in the area.

We found Season 52 from other Yelpers. I appreciated the idea that nothing on the menu was more than 500 calories. The fact that it is part of chain made me a little apprehensive, but the menu all looked quite good. We were seated right away. The piano player added a nice feel to the place. With the calorie restriction I was worried about portion size. We got  the caprese salad for a starter. Fresh flavorful tomatoes, lightly fried mozz with a nice balsamic and basil. Very Good! I ordered the lamb and my wife had the scallops. All were delicious and more than I could eat. The lamb had a nice crust and perfectly medium rare. Lots be good crisp veges in the plate. We are already looking forward to our next visit.

Never got a chance to try the food due to the abysmal service here. After our waitress dumped an entire round of beers down the back of one of our group members, we waited for at least 5-10 minutes before she came back to ask for our drink orders. Um, what? Instead of apologizing and offering a wet washcloth or comped round of drinks, she acted as if nothing had happened even though our friend told her she was soaked in beer. Terrible. We walked out shortly after that. I hope their menu and other waitstaff make up for it because the hostess also appeared completely oblivious to the situation, saying "have a great night" after we had been seated no less than 10 minutes before in the dining room.

I had a gift card for the Darden restaurant group that Seasons 52 is a part of.  I had never been there before, and the Loop location is not somewhere I usually go for dinner.  But, on a chilly evening a few months back, we finally headed out of the house for a nice dinner on the town. There is a piano behind the bar, so the live music adds a nice touch to the dining experience.  That may have been one of my favorite parts. :)  The service was great throughout--our server actually had a personality and was very pleasant. We started off our meal by sharing a flatbread.  It had artichokes and goat cheese and was delicious!  For my entree, I ordered the scallops that came with Israeli couscous.  They were flavorful, and I really enjoyed the couscous.  We ended our meal with the mini indulgences.  I had the chocolate peanut butter torte.  I'm sure it would have been fantastic if it were served chilled, however, it was room temperature and didn't taste all that great. All in all, I would dine here again if I was in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to.

Place has a cool vibe.  Though it is in rive north..its not noisy and overcrowded. All entrees are under 475 calories but still delicious . They have a decent wine list too..GreaT option for veggie folks too.. Turkey kebabs and  Flat bread were amazing ! we finished off with perfectly sized desserts which were equally YUMMMM !!

Do it. I've been to 3 Seasons 52, Dallas, Plano and Chicago. I go at least twice a month for several reasons.  1. Service- the service is top-notch. Always 2. Food! We all love food and theirs is expertly prepared, and the ONE time they messed on my steak (wrong temperature) the chef himself delivered a brand new one to me personally. And then comped it.  3. Ambiance: Whether its girls night, date night or mom's birthday this place fits the bill.  4. Diet Friendly: Did I mention everything is under 500 calories and STILL chock full of flavor? Like I said, be like Nike, and Just Do It.

I ordered the summer vegetable "skillet corn" and that was AMAZINGly delish!  I also had the salmon salad with mango, pineapple, jimica & more... very good as well.   Service was great the first half of the evening but when the bar got a little busier, service started to decline.  I get it, they got busy but it took very long to get the desert menu, a take out box and my check.

Never a bad meal at any seasons 52 I have been too. I like that they are some what health conscious with their portions, but they still leave you satisfied. Every bite of everything we ordered was delicious. From the edamame to the lump crab salad (summer menu). They change their menu items (some remain constant through every season) each season, which makes it enjoyable to go to every few weeks. Always something new to try. Their flatbreads are awesome as well! Kelly is also a GREAT waitress! Recommended for a yummy, healthy, and quick if you need it to be meal.

Love going to Seasons 52! The food is so delicious and fresh, always prepared to perfection. Try their infused martinis, my fav is the organic sunshine martini. The restaurant is beautiful, perfect for a romantic date. Outstanding service every time I go!
This place is great! The food is fantastic and the experience you get is second to none. Not to mention the staff is exceptional and very friendly!

Food & service were great. I came for my 21st birthday and had to change the reservation several times due to late RSVPs and the restaurant staff were very accommodating and polite when dealing with my constantly changing reservation. Very good place to go for big parties, I had a reservation of 14 people. I ordered the shrimp cavatappi pasta and it was very good!

My wife and I heard great things about Seasons 52 from several friends. Let me just say, this place lives up to the hype. We truly enjoyed the freshness of the food and the number of ingredients that were used from local sources.  The flavors were exceptional and well worth the slightly higher prices than your typical chain sit-down restaurants. The portion sizes were generous without pushing you over the top and the desserts were the perfect amount to cap off the meal.  Our server, Jeff, was very friendly from the start, knowledgable about the menu, and courteous.  The atmosphere was calm and had a warm feel to it. The music selection was enjoyable and got even better after 6pm with live piano.  We will definitely be returning and recommending Seasons 52 to our friends and family.

We were in Chicago for our anniversary and made reservations elsewhere. We decided to change our minds and go with Seasons 52 (Mostly because they had open reservations last minute on a Saturday night!). It was not a bad choice. I had salmon and my wife had chicken. We had a flatbread as an appetizer with prosciutto and asparagus that was really good! In my mind it seemed like it was pricey just because it was Chicago. I feel as though I could have gotten the same meal downstate for half the price. With that said, our waitress was really nice and did a good job of seeing to our needs the entire time we were there. The atmosphere was pleasant and made for an enjoyable evening out. I have nothing overly bad to say about Seasons 52 but nothing overly great to say either.

This place has a pretty cool vibe. There is live music in the front, which on the night that we were there was something to avoid. The guy was singing off key and kind of yelling. Not the best atmosphere while you are drinking a glass of good wine. I had the Grilled Garlic Pesto Chicken flatbread for an appetizer. It was good, but not great. I know that this is a low-fat, healthier place, and given that specialization, the flatbread was flavorful. What was it missing? Uh, fat. Give me some more olive oil if you are not going to layer it in cheese. My wife had Lump Crab, Roasted Shrimp & Spinach Stuffed Mushrooms for her appetizer. Again, because the dish had so little fat (some parmesan cheese), the spinach's wateriness dulled the flavor. Again, it was tasty for what it was trying to be, but it was definitely not the best stuffed mushroom that i have had. For our entrees we had the grilled trout and the filet mignon. I hate to sound like a broken record, and I KNOW I was at a lower fat restaurant, but the red wine sauce for the filet was missing something--BUTTER! And the trout was a little dry. Finally, this place prides itself on its wine pairings. Our waitress, however, didn't seem to know very much about wine. I knew more than she did. The wines are good, don't get me wrong; but when I look for a recommendation, I want to try something that I might not order on my own, rather than have a waitress tell me, "Well the Cab is really good with red meat." No kidding, Nancy Drew. Overall, if you are limited in your diet, this is a good place to get a good, tasty, healthy meal with a decent wine list. If you're like me and you would miss the fat, even if your doctor would recommend that you eat less, I would try somewhere else and spend another 45 minutes on the elliptical.
We will be return customers!  Appetizer lobster flatbread, Copper River Salmon entrée, and dessert were each excellent!

Great service and comfortable atmosphere. We shared several appetizers, the mushrooms and egg rolls were great. The sauces with the chicken skewers were kind of bland. Nice wine selection and Elizabeth was great and we had a good time.

First time at this location. I've eaten at the one in Orlando before and this one was just as good.  Their menu changes 4 times a year based on the season and all entrées are under 475 calories.  Got the roma tomato flatbread for an appetizer and the scallops for an entrée.  I could not believe the exceptional amount of scallops I got for the price.  Cocktails are generous -- the martini I ordered was basically 2 drinks.  Wine selection is phenomenal.  The service was impeccable.  Although this is a chain restaurant, I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes fresh food, delicious cocktails, and a great wine selection.
A really great place to go for swanky drinks and hors d'oeuvres. The staff is super pleasant and accommodating. The drinks are amazing, especially the wine.

Happened upon this place completely by accident. And so happy we did! Service was fabulous. And the food was amazing. 475 calories of deliciousness!  We started with the seasonal lobster and shrimp spring rolls and the shrimp cocktail. The cocktail sauce is full of horseradish, as it should be. Both were great starters. The BF got the lobster flatbread - also seasonal. It was light and lemony and so good! I had the scallops. They were perfectly cooked. The risotto was amazing. I can't say enough about this place! Try the cucumber basil smash - so good!

I went here for a Yelp event and loved it! I had been to the one in Schaumburg, but was a lot more impressed with this location. Brian, the manager, is really nice and you can tell he really cares that people enjoy the restaurant. The food was delicious and the service was fantastic. I will definitely be back!

ALL meals under 475 calories... a sure way to a lady's heart!  Best way to allow her to taste as many wines as possible ;-)  Hubby and I began w the yummy Shrimp cocktail... he decided on the Full rack of Lamb... happily so! I enjoyed the Maui Tuna Crunch - all to myself! Of course, I upgraded my Flight of Red vinos... only $5 more :-) I am such a Cab Sav girl... after trying all 3... my fav was the Seven Falls '10 Cab Sav, 2nd runner up... St Hallet '12 Shiraz... though, the Tarima Hill rated 93, it was not for me...  not bad... just, not me. The service at Seasons 52 was great! Jay Jay took care of us... he offered us great service and w such a great attitude!  Thanks!!!  Make sure you stop by and enjoy yourself!  Your constant companion,  ~ deirdra

I came for a great event that was in the front bar area.  The restaurant is in a great location and the decor was nice, but not too stuffy or pretentious.  I have to mention that the cocktail reception I went to meant everything was free for me, so I can't comment on the pricing.  Brian, the manager came out and was extremely helpful and introduced himself and asked if he could help.  The bar area is surrounded by nice booths that range in sizes and create cute little areas to chat with friends.  The drinks were stiff and well mixed.  The bites to eat were delicious, especially the flatbread pizzas and the chicken skewers.  Excellent service and a piano singer behind the bar added to the good time.  Abby (the singer) performs on Wednesdays and Sundays and she sang a great mix of contemporary songs with a twist.  Overall, a great time and I'll be back for dinner to try more from the menu soon!

I went to Season's 52 for an event and since I checked myself in, I am writing a review, but it's a little difficult to write this review. The place is very nicely decorated and a pretty location, that I would enjoy going for a nice dinner or a date. The hostess was very welcoming. When i walked into my event, I was immediately handed a glass of the house white wine, which was very nice. The bartender and all workers seemed very nice too. Then I waited and waited and waited. No food to be had. The rare occasion I saw a plate of food, it was swarmed so quickly that I could not get anything. After 2 hours, I tried 1 stuffed mushroom, 1 triangle of the pesto flatbread, 1 skewer of lamb, and a shot glass of cheesecake. From these few bites, the food seems very good. I will try to go back as some point to really try the place out.

I came here for an event. I like the look and the layout of the place very much. Very good service, and very helpful too, especially since they add the personal touch. Brian Termini is the marketing manager and he was warm and welcoming, came to talk to all the tables and introduce himself.  We had the flatbread and chicken and lamb skewers, as well as pesto mushrooms. Call outs to the chicken pesto flatbread- delicious! as well as the lamb skewers. They have a good wine selection as well and have a deal for flatbread and wine through the week that is worth checking out. They also have a private dining space in the back for larger parties

The service was fantastic. I had the half chicken, which was sub-par at best. then again, when meals are based on calorie intake they probably have to sacrifice some flavor. The dessert was good, many options and all are readily prepared to pick and eat. -3 out of 5. *Cheers
Appetizer were amazing, especially the flatbread.  The scallops were prepared to perfection - tender and delicious.

Came here for happy hour with seven others. Most of us got the $15 flight w/ flatbread special. Everyone agreed that it was a stellar deal and good quality. The waitress did tell me a little secret that you can order the flight without the flatbread for $10 since we had so many people and she thought there might be too many flatbreads. We upgraded one to the lobster one for $5 and had a great time. On the way out we each got a leftover Easter $25 giftcard to return!  We tried all the flatbreads and the order of popularity: Pesto chicken/ Artichoke tied, Roma tomato, Lobster then Steak Other cocktail tried and liked: Prairie Mule - delicious!  Cucumber basil- a little sweet, but you can ask them to mix in more soda Some orange martini- delicious!

Seasons 52 was a great option for our group. We had seven people, almost all of which ordered one of the wine flights which comes with 3 wines and then one full glass of your favorite. We tried all the flatbreads which were all very tasty. The artichoke was my favorite. Then we followed it up with some cocktails. The cucumber basil smash with extra lime juice and club soda was perfect. The service was also very attentive and willing to customize. Would recommend to any group.

After 4 visits, I couldn't love this place more. I was once a server and am typically hard to please because of this, but the service here is consistently excellent. I'd gladly request MJ, Joe or Maria by name based on how pleasant and attentive they each were. The food is so fresh and delicious. Highly recommend the filet here. The fact that all the items are 475 calories or less is mind blowing based on all the options and flavor. The fact that they have a specific menu that is dairy-free but not vegan is HUGE to me. I have a dairy allergy but I still eat meat, so it's a pain to often be forced to choose vegan options to guarantee no dairy. And the gluten free menu is great for friends of mine. The live jazz is so pleasant every night. Seasons 52 is my new favorite spot!

Great Food, Piano Bar and Manager (Charles) make anniversary dinner an evening to remember.  Highly recommend, the menu changes with the Season and have never had a bad meal here.  Piano player in bar was awesome, and took requests.  Minor service hiSeason 52 cares about their food and patrons.

Me and my bf were the only patrons under the age of 50 here. Didnt know every entree is under 500 calories-- pretty nice for us old folks and fatsos. I had the turkey, the rice pilaf was so bland I wish I couldve gotten more calories. Wont be back.
Great service, live piano, excellent wine selection, fab food and each dish is under 475 calories!

Yes its a chain but its a good one.  Service was unbelievable. Just a very attentive staff.  A friend and I went for what seemed like an early dinner after work and I thought for such a large restaurant it was surprisingly empty.  Not so much... about a half hour in, there was a piano singer at the bar and the place was poppin like it was a Saturday night.  Its price point is definitely aimed for the tourists and business types that frequent the area but quality and service are such a winner it doesn't feel cliche.  Appetizers are good but after a couple a sips of temparnillo wine who remembers?  I ordered the shrimp dish because I liked the sides that came with and my friend ordered the scallops.  He not much of a sharer but I tasted the scallops and tried hard not to be jealous.  Here comes the interesting part.  The waiter comes by and asked about our food and I say love the shrimp but should have gotten the scallops.  Without blinking he offers to bring out another dish!!  Wow.  I love it when staff are actually empowered to give good customer service!! Anyway I decline out of kindness to the server.  A couple minutes later, Ozzie, I am guessing a manager asks the same question.  So I tell'em my story.  He says okay but maybe I have a surprise for you.  And within minutes a lovely half-order of these large,lovely buttery perfectly broiled scallops come out and I am a 6 yr old looking at my birthday cake, ALL SMILES!! So good, so good.  Do yourself a favor and order the scallops.  Desserts are these wonderfully small little cups that allow for a nice taste without regrets. Yay, Seasons 52!  I'm a fan

I'm really not a fan of chain restaurants... But, this place was a PLEASANT surprise.  It was a Friday night and we didn't have reservations, so my husband and I were seated in the bar area. It was a bit loud, but thats to be expected, especially with live music.   (The talent, John had a great voice. BTW)  The place had sort-of a 'jazzy' kind of vibe to it. It definitely was set to impress middle-aged business men. The thing I appreciated most was the warm and low romantic lighting.   My husband owns a personal training company and we both try to eat very clean and healthy. In a city like Chicago, this feels like an impossibility. Well, well, well...what a pleasant surprise!  This was our first visit to Seasons and we had no idea their 'shtick' was offering calorie-controlled menu options! KA-CHING!  For appetizers I had the chicken skewers with corn relish.  The chicken was the perfect amount of spicy...not too much and not too little.  It was so flavorful that I didn't need to use the dipping sauce. Yay! My husband ordered the lamb appetizer and said the meat was juicy and tender and the portion size was very good. We both had the petite filet with a side of asparagus.  The meat was tender and cut like butter.  The preparation was simple and clean. Usually, we don't order dessert. But because the servings were small and portion controlled...it was hard to have control!  We caved. Here are the sweet treats we tried: 1. The peanut butter and chocolate pudding 2. Brownie with raspberry sauce 3. Machiatto something I thought the Machiatto thing was the best. (I like sweet!) My husband liked the Brownie with raspberry sauce.   Heather, our server was very friendly and so was the hostess staff. fearlessfitness.ltd.com  will definitely be spreading the great news about Seasons 52. Any person looking for a healthy and tasty place to indulge without feeling too guilty needs to check this place out.

Had a great time at Seasons 52 for my 30th bday dinner. We had made a reservation and was seated immediately. There was a nice birthday card on behalf of Seasons 52 that was waiting on the table. Our server, JJ, was fantastic. He was extremely knowledgable about the menu and waa able to help us pick items based on his personal favorites. I had the stuffed mushrooms, grilled pear salad, butternut squash soup and a mini key lime pie shooter; all equally delicious. Just to let you know each food item on the menu is less zhan 500 cals...even some entire meals! Talk about guilt free. I had a great time and the part that topped it all off was the great soundsystem and live singer that was covering contemporary pop tunes.

I think what I love about Seasons 52 is how everytime I've gone, no matter where, the waitstaff is eager to please and attentive.  This is a great place to go for appetizers or dinner.  Food is really good.  We started with the 2 flatbreads of blue cheese/steak, and Artichoke and Goat cheese.  Both were really yummy, the artichoke one being a little heavy on the onion and a little light on the artichoke and goat cheese, but still good.  We ordered up spinach stuffed mushrooms but they needed something extra.  Maybe more garlic or a spice.  I then moved to the scallops and asparagus, and they were well cooked, a little undercooked on both but still very good.  Desserts we had in those little shot glasses which I guess make you feel less guilty but we ordered many and shared our spoon germs.  We got a raspberry chocolate thing, a mocha mousse (my fave) and a pecan pie/vanilla mousse (a little too much sweet--I can't believe I'm saying that).  The only thing I wasn't terrribly impressed with was the wine list.  I tried a couple and our waitress was eager to please but I just couldn't find one that tasted new.  This is a great place to go if you have vegetarians or vegans in your group as they cater completely to any food allergies, preferences, etc.

This is my 1st visit to this lovely mahogany niche in the River North area.  According to lovely and gracious Jamie @ the main bar the menu changes every season and the right panel every week. What a delightful concept! I started  out with a glass of delicious Indaba Chardonnay. Then I fished out the Grilled Boneless Rainbow Trout-a seafood must. For dessert I was shown a tray of yummy desserts by flashlight. I chose the decadent to die for Mocha Macchiato selection. Every dish is under 475 calories according to Jamiie. Live music every night. I'll be back in the spring.

Went to Seasons52 on Friday for Valentines Day with my wife and another couple. We usually do not go out on Valentines Day because the restaurants overbook and jam in more tables but we thought we would give this place a shot. So glad we did. The food and service were outstanding.Our server Lindsay was knowledgeable, friendly and attentive. Water glasses were kept filled and courses arrived in a timely,but not rushed, pace  The restaurant gave each female a rose and our meal started with a nice vegetable amuse. The flatbreads are good and nice to share but the mushrooms stuffed with crab, shrimp, and spinach was my favorite app.I will order this as long as it stays on the menu. The menu changes seasonally (hence the name Seasons 52) and no course is more than 475 calories. Since the menu changes regularly I wont get into everyone's meal but will tell you there was not one course that was a disappointment for any of us. I will say I had the cavatappi pasta and shrimp that I had was delicious  was perfectly prepared. I really enjoyed the live piano bar.The guy playing that night was excellent but they told me they rotate about 4 entertainers. Nice wine list and the drinks were good.They use organic vodka for the Prairie mule. The room is is set up nicely and the noise level is very good. One can actually have a conversation without screaming across the table.  Also, I appreciate that the GM walks around and makes sure each table is happy with the meal. Thanks to Ozzie and his staff for making our dinner such a great experience. Not always easy to do on holidays but this man obviously knows how to run a restaurant. We will be back soon

This place was fantastic. I went with my fiance for Valentine's Day and we had a lovely dinner. We were first given complimentary glasses of champagne and I was given a rose. We were also given a complimentary taste from the chef of one of the appetizers. We ordered a lobster flatbread which I would highly recommend. When they say flat bread...it truly is very thin-almost like a cracker. I then ordered the salmon which was perfect. It is really great to know that all the menu options are less than 475 calories per item. I would also recommend the drink I got which was a pomegranate margarita martini. It was strong but you could not really taste the alcohol. Also the pianist was phenomenal. I actually wanted to get his card but forgot. He played and sang all sorts of current hits in a very subtle and romantic way. I wanted to tip him but he was sitting behind the bar and it was not set up for tips. The desserts looked amazing but we ended up going next door to Eataly, which honestly I would've rather had the desserts from Seasons 52. All in all a great dinner and I will definitely return to this restaurant.

Not going back. Why you ask? Well, I will tell you. I have now gone to this location twice with my girlfriend. Once about a month after they opened and once during restaurant week. My GF has raved about the other locations so i thought i would take her.  We experienced terrible service both times. Our water glasses were never full after the first filling at the beginning of our meal. The food was luke warm and never hot, even after sending it back it would come back out the same. not that i condone it but PUT IT IN THE MICROWAVE if you really can't keep it hot.  The restaurant week menu was way too much food, a tasting menu would have sufficed. We actually had our main course wrapped to go. We were overfull.  The staff never apologized for any issues until I wrote corporate. Then i received a call from the GM.  This place is brutal

Amazing Service!  I'm not usually a big fan of chain restaurnats, but this place is fantastic.  I'd been to the ones in the burbs and always been pleased with the food, so decided to try the city version.  I ordered a venison chop medium rare.  It came out closer to well done, so I sent it back.  Our server offered to buy me a soup or appetizer to eat while I waited, which I didn't need, so I declined.  Then when my dish came out the second time, the chef personally delivered it & apologized.  The chop was perfect & delicious, and I enjoyed every bite.  At the end of our meal, our server insisted on treating us to his favorite dessert on the house, and when the bill came, we weren't even charged for the chop!  It is rare to find that kind of customer service these days.
We visited during restaurant week. The menu was excuisite! We loved the little moose desserts. Will return for sure. Not 5 stars because valet gave my tire a flat.

The only reason I'm giving Seasons 52 two stars is because the food was great...once we got it; service was AWFUL.  I went to Season 52 for "restaurant week" because I really liked their menu and vast options they had available. All started out well; service was great in the beginning, got our wine and flat-breads in record speed, but then things went downhill.  The chef came out and asked how we enjoyed the flat-breads (which they were amazing), and then said the soup would be right up.  Right up, meaning 45 mins later...finally that showed up (come on how long can it take to pour soup into a bowl).  Then the waitress came out to clear the soup bowls and mentioned to us that we would have to pick a different salad or appetizer since the kitchen ran out of pears for the pear salad.  Then miraculously the pears appeared 20 mins later so we ended up getting the pear salad (I'm sure someone ran to Jewel quick to buy them out of pears...which was fine because the salad was great).  Before the entrees showed up, the chef made an appearance yet again to apologize about the slowness of the service saying our entree's would be right up. At that time I wanted to ask the chef politely to please box up our entrees and dessert so we could leave since we had been sitting there for 2 hours already. About 15 mins after the chef showed up for the 2nd time our main entree's finally showed up (the filet was amazing and others I dined with had the scallops and said they were good). By that time people in my group were getting annoyed with the slow service and just wanted to get dessert and take off.  All while this was going on, I was watching the tables around us...they got served right away, ate and left (and I can imagine they were all dining for restaurant week as well).  Finally when we got dessert, it was about 2 hours and 45 mins after we got seated.  I am fine with a 3 hour dining experience if I'm in Europe or taking a client out for dinner...but with a group of friends that had to work the next day...I would have been fine with 2 hours.  Finally Jesse the Manager stopped by our table and apologized for the service and the slow kitchen.  He then handed us a $25 gift card (that had to be used by 2/14) and couldn't be used that night.  It was a nice gesture, but I don't think anyone in my group will be returning anytime soon.
Went back again for lunch today and once again everything was delish!

We tried out Seasons 52 on a snowy cold Saturday lunch. We went quite late so the restaurant was empty. We received a gift certificate of $35 so we thought we would try it out. The restaurant is big, with a very wooden feel with many wine bottles displayed around the seating area. I ordered a flatbread pizza (grilled chicken) which I highly recommend, as it was thin and crispy with the right amount of topping. I also got the tuna burger which was tasty as well with a wasabi mayo sauce accompanying it. The prices of the dishes are very reasonable and it helps knowing that every dish is below 475 calories! I also had the roasted potatoes as a side. That was probably the only dish that I would think had lost a little on taste due to trying to keep below the 475 calories as they were roasted instead of fried but still very tasty. The service was perfect, we had a friendly server that was very knowledgable that recommended us a couple of dishes. At the end the meal she brought out the mini indulgence desserts very well displayed which would tempt any person to try one! Great place for those health conscious people trying to eat reasonably sized portions.

I have never left a Seasons 52 disappointed, and today was no different. We came for their restaurant week lunch menu and for $22 a person it is a ton of food. Healthy and delicious food at that. We each ordered flatbreads for course one; Roma tomato mozzarella and garlic pesto chicken so we could share. I was almost full just after eating those! For my main course I got the braised mole beef tacos that had jalapeño cilantro lime slaw, pickled red onions, guacamole, and a tomatillo salsa on the side. I could eat those every single day and be happy. As my choice of a side I got the quinoa and citrus grains salad. I wasn't as crazy for that simply because it had dried cherries which I don't care for and clashed with tacos.  My husband got the ahi tuna crunch salad with roasted potato wedges and he loved all of it. I tried the fries and they were perfect. Baked, not fried but still with wonderful flavor and a nice crispy exterior. We were pretty much ready to burst at this point, but alas we still had dessert. They are mini dessert shooters, so trust me you have room even if you think you are full! I got the mocha macchiato one with whipped cream, chocolate shavings, and a yummy shaved chocolate straw. My husband got the pecan pie one and it was very rich. At dinner our waitress said the restaurant week menu is five courses so my advice is come hungry. This is by far one of our favorite restaurants in the city. They change their menu seasonally so they can highlight items at their peak making each meal extra special. Treat yourself and take advantage of using their valet.

My friends and I tried this place out for lunch during restaurant week. When we got there, no valet guy was to be found, and the hostess was completely clueless and said we should park in the parking lot. When we walked in after parking, we were immediately greeted and the hostess told us they would be able to validate our parking for a discount. When we left, their "validation" was simply giving us cash to pay for the parking. Nice save!  Now about the meal. Service was awesome! The waitress and every one who helped service our table were extremely nice. But why three stars you ask? Well, the highlight of the meal was the flatbread we ordered as our appetizer. All the food that came after was mediocre. Portions were huge and flavors were okay. The boys ordered bison burgers; eh it was okay. Nothing special, a little on the dry side. The potato wedges that came with the order tasted chewy, a very odd texture for potato wedges. My sister and I each ordered a salad. Decent, but nothing to rave about. And my other friend ordered the mole tacos, which were just okay.  In addition to our gargantuous meal, we opted to try the tamale tots and Fuji apple slaw. The tamale tots were mushy. Not at all what we were expecting. The Fuji apple slaw was delicious, a tad bit on the sweet side though. Lastly, desserts. We were pretty stuffed at this point, but had to still taste the desserts. Not bad, but I would say choose chocolate anything. They were pretty solid.  All in all, food was okay. But, I would probably come back for the flatbread and the excellent service!

We ate at Seasons 52 during Restaurant Week and had the tasting lunch. We had previously been to their restaurant in Oak Brook, so we knew the concept (reasonable calories). Out waiter (Heather) was very helpful and friendly, with just the right amount of attention and helpful input on choices. We were surprised by the spinach salad, which was quite large. It was reasonably dressed and tasty. The beef tacos were nicely spicy without being overbearing; they seemed to have enough filling for a full-size taco in a slightly smaller shell. The green salsa provided a nice extra punch. The chicken also came with a nice sauce and was a fairly large serving. The potato wedges came with a very nice dipping sauce. And we love the mini-desserts, which are small enough to eat more than one, if you're so inclined, without feeling too guilty about it. My only reservation about the place is the decor, which is California/corporate/slick - I'd rather have a little lighter/more open feeling (it's not actually crowded, it just feels dark).

Now here's a place that did Restaurant Week right! The food was really tasty, full size portions, service was great. Nothing precious or trendy, just good food, fun, old school piano bar, and did I mention the food was really good?  Seasons 52, you have a new fan!

My girlfriend and I went yesterday for Restaurant Week (RW), and I thought I'd breakdown my overall experience. Pros: -Nice ambience, interior to the restaurant; there was even a piano man during the meal -You get your money's worth on the RW menu  -The steak and bleu cheese flatbread was very good -The individual dessert servings were tasty and refreshing Cons: -Too much food on the RW menu, so we were pretty much full by the time our entrees came out.  A tasting menu should be an appropriate amount of food picked out by the restaurant -The seafood tasted 'off' -- like funky crab or something -- in the stuffed mushrooms -The soup was like a french onion with beef chunks, which didn't pack much flavor -I experienced one of the worst food poisonings in my life.  My girlfriend and I shared everything besides our entrees (I had the filet, and she had the salmon), so I imagine the filet was the issue.  The filet looked like a good piece of meat, cooked how I requested it, but it was covered in a 'red wine sauce' that reminded me of a salisbury steak from middle school.  Why take a nice piece of meat and cover it with a glaze?  Let it speak for itself if it's a good cut.  When we left the restaurant, I thought I was just uncomfortably full, but instead I got uncontrollably sick. Thoughts: RW is usually a good way to try a restaurant and get a good feel for the place.  Initially, I thought Seasons 52 was decent, but after not being able to sleep for more than an hour last night, I will not be returning.

The food here was good, the wait staff attentive and pleasant.  However, the parking rate that is posted outside applies to only three hours at that rate.  It jumps from $14 to $18 if you go over that limit. There were two of us for dinner on a Monday night when the restaurant was not busy.  We both commented how long it was taking to be served.   Anyway, it came as a surprise when the parking fee went to $18.  I live on the Gold Cost and am not unfamiliar with parking.  I don't know if the upcharge relates to where Seaons 52 parks the cars, but this is a pricey fee. It makes me realize why many people don't want to bother coming into town for dinner.

Friday night and we need a spot to check out.  With the new year and new resolutions to eat healthier and blah, blah, blah, I guess we were looking for something a bit healthier to check out.   And whaddaya know, we had a nice mailer that gave us $35 off at Seasons 52, a reasonably new addition to Chicago, Seasons 52 is a nationwide upscale dining chain, with a focus on natural ingredients and comfort foods. It's big schtick is that all of their dishes are under 440 calories, which in a world that is increasingly more health-conscious, is a pretty good schtick to have.  Looking down the standard menu, there's a pretty good variety of dishes that are clearly healthier and easy to keep in that calorie range, and they save some calories with some of the entree-type dishes by cutting back on portion sizes and shrinking the role of the carb-heavy sides.  On top of the standard menu, there were a number of seasonal specials that were extremely enticing as well. In the end, we each got an entree and split an appetizer, so to get a dinner meal knowing that it was under 660 calories was a bonus.  Started with the lobster, scallion, and sweet pepper flatbread that had a good mix of flavors and textures.  The lobster was chopped pretty small, but added a good meatiness, but lacked a bit of flavor.  The scallions had a nice sharp bite, and the sweet peppers balanced the dish out with a softer texture.  The flatbread itself was nice and thin with a good crisp, slightly burnt crust. For entree #1, we  got the Mesquite-grilled garlic shrimp with saffron-chorizo risotto - good portion size.  It had a nice char, but in the process, the shrimp was a bit overcooked, so it lacked that soft meatiness.  The flavor itself was a subtle garlicky, and the supporting players - the risotto and broccolini were pretty average.  The risotto was a bit gummy and overcooked, and heavy on olives, which overpowered the dish, and there's not much to say about broccolini - simple preparation The second entree was a whole roasted branzino (the smallest branzino I've seen) from the specials menu - In the end, it was much better than the above dish.  While the portion size was small, it was solidly cooked. Branzino is a Mediterranean seabass, mostly found in Italian dishes.  It has a soft, buttery texture, and at Seasons, they topped it off with a lemon butter that added to the overall smoothness of the fish (and again, it's under 440 calories!).  The supporting cast - a trio of roasted white and purple potatoes and some grilled broccolini and red peppers were simple but a solid addition to the dish. The desserts at Seasons are also under 440 calories, but that's because they serve them in shot glasses. There was a good mix, but we passed on dessert, as Eataly, a block north, was calling our name.   In the end, Seasons 52 is a great idea, but the prices unfortunately don't always drop to the extent that the portion sizes do, which make it difficult to justify the cost if I'm paying full price.   Thankfully, with the mailer, the total bill with tax and tip came out to well under $50. eatinginchicago2014.word…

This place should be in the parking lot of a suburban mall. It's nicely decorated and smells like wood burning fire. That's where it ends the food is lackluster and the service is amateur. Not worthy of a off Michigan Avenue location. Very expensive too. There are so many wonderful places to eat in the neighborhood. No need to stop here.  They brought the wrong dish for one of us and then charged us for the incorrect plate. Dropped the check and then disappeared for 10 minutes. Lunch for four was $140 with no cocktails or beverages.  Kind of a ripoff considering the service was sub par and the food was merely average.

My son and I popped in for a late lunch experience here at Seasons 52. The place was impressive to walk into, altho there was no one at the front to greet us. We stood for a time when a hostess finally appeared , grabbed a ringing phone and motioned for us to wait. I wanted to sit down and warm up after walking a few blocks in the blustery weather that was hitting the city that day, but it was only a 4 min wait or so. We were then promptly seated in a booth that ran adjacent to the bar, actually the serving station of the bar.  Our server was pleasant but insincere and the restaurant empty except for one other booth in the bar area occupied. I thought 4 PM was time for a tummy warming cocktail and had ordered a Hendricks rocks. 13.50..wow..my son had a hot coffee whisky libation with toffee. very nice. We started our meal with the Lobster flatbread pizza, which was decadent altho it came out cold.But the Lobster was generous and the lemongrass infused it beautifully. Ryan ordered a Caesar baby Kale salad with grilled Shrimp for his main..an 18 dollar salad btw...and I opted for the Buffalo Burger which came out steaming and juicy on a toasted bun. I loathed the Truffle Aioli. But that was served on the side thankfully.  All in all, good atmosphere if a little lax, good food but a bit pricey for a late lunch menu. I found it a good place to get out of the cold and enjoy a pricey Gin and tasty morsels.
Wonderful meal from start to finish. The flatbread was terrifically crispy. The turkey tips were smoky and flavorful. The sugar free cookies and cream mousse was decadent.

Tried out Seasons 52 with some friends and while I'm not falling over myself to go back there, I did enjoy my food and server was really nice and attentive. I did find it stranger that our waiter was also the bartender, but whatever. The location of the restaurant could either be a gold mine or a bust. Being located downtown surrounded by so many hotels and offices you would think that this place would have a steady flow of customers, but the place was pretty much dead. There is so much competition downtown with restaurants so any new restaurant is going to have to go above and beyond to draw people in.  If you're downtown I do recommend you give Seasons 52 a try. The food was good and we all left full. What we had: * Lump Crab, Roasted Shrimp & Spinach Stuffed Mushrooms under Parmesan-panko crust {These were AMAZING} * Tamale Tots with red mole & chili sour cream dipping sauce {SKIP THIS} * Red Mole Braised Beef Tacos with jalapeño-lime slaw, guacamole, pickled red onion {You get three tacos and they are a good size. This dish has a kick to it} * Grilled Jumbo Shrimp Cavatappi Pasta with spinach, mushrooms, garlic, sour cream, & roasted tomatoes {The shrimp were lightly seasoned, a decent size and you get about 4 - 6. The pastas was perfectly cooked} * Caramelized Grilled Sea Scallops with roasted asparagus, sun-dried tomato-mushroom pearl pasta {While you get 6 medium size scallops, which were plump and tasty, I found myself wishing I had gotten one of the above dishes my dining companions got} Dessert: All the desserts are mini size and they all look delicious, except for the Market Fresh Fruit. We got the Belgian Chocolate Rocky Road dessert (2 apiece) and gave this dessert 2 thumbs up.

This location needs to find its footing. I will chalk it up to newly open growing pains. As a recent FL transplant I am not only familiar with Seasons 52, I am a HUGE fan. So, imagine my disappointment with a less than lack luster experience my first time here. We went late on a Monday afternoon. Valet didn't show up, so we parked in the garage literally attached to the restaraunt. BEWARE this garage apparently is NOT associated with them and they can't validate. To be fair, the manager on duty went above and beyond to assist in rectifying the situation since the valet was MIA and garage charges would have been $38.  We were sat in the bar, we felt rushed by our waitress the entire time. She was also the bartender at the time. There were only 3 other tables in the restaurant no need to push. She was awkward, clumsy and lacked personality. It really killed the mood of lunch.  I will give them a few months to find their way and pray they find their way in service to the restaurant I fell in live with in FL.

3 stars due to kitchen issues, not due to quality of service or the food. We ordered wine flights and dflat bread as startwrs, one of the orders was late and the manager comped all the flatbreads for our party. Wine service was slow due to our waiter being very busy aso he comped our desserts.  I had the flank steak salad, as the main, very good. My recommendation is to try the wine flights, then pick any large salad and you will enjoy your evening,

Old boys club with a modern menu that tries hard to stay out of the grave. There was a man in the center of the bar playing a keyboard and singing Walking in Memphis - and not in a good way, unless you crave an up-scale Cheers type of ambiance. The seasonal vegetable melange was good, the soft taco in particular, the stuffed mushrooms were average, the beet salad was nice, and the goat cheese ravioli was delicious. The wait staff was very kind and patient, evident when we asked to be moved twice (as far away from piano man as possible).

The food is great but the service was slow. The nice thing about this place is that a section of the menu gets updated weekly depending on the season. Also any item on the menu is less than 475 cal, which is great but this means that you should be expecting smaller than usual portions at a somewhat pricey place. The best part of the dinner was dessert, the chocolate peanut butter mousse is delicious.

I first ate at Seasons 52 in Kansas City and I loved it.  So I had high hopes when one opened in Chicago. But this place has a lot of work to do. I showed up on a Friday night and put my name in at the host stand.  Even though there were tables available immediately, I had to wait five minutes for reasons unknown. When I was finally shown to my table, the waiter came over and shook my hand.  What?  Neither of us knows where our hands have been and I'm about to use mine to eat food, so I'm not a fan of touching strangers.  That was odd. Despite that weirdness, our server was a nice guy.  We ordered a trio of flatbreads.  The pesto garlic chicken one was the winner of the night. But by the end of the meal, I had a pounding headache because of... the piano player.  This dude sounds like Tony Bennett and Scott Joplin had a baby.  And then the baby had a stroke.  I took video of his horrible performance.  Enjoy:  youtu.be/1lX92IkUHpw And he was LOUD.  Like, couldn't-hear-my-girlfriend-across-the-table loud.  And he was cheesy.  Like, Bill-Murray-as-Nick-the-lounge-singer cheesy.  Except unfunny. There IS seating away from this atrocious musician, so I'd recommend trying to nab a table in the other room. I seem to recall the prices in Kansas City were far more reasonable than what I noticed on the Chicago menu.  Location, location, location, I guess.

I really liked this place...not only that you got a free flatbread when ordering a wine flight (what a deal!)...but everything is under 600 calories but yet taste sooo good! i like most of the flatbread, esp the steak & blue cheese and the trio mushroom.. and i can't believe the quails stuffed with mushroom risotto entree is also under 600 calories!! SO GOOD! so flavourful!  the brussel sprout was delightful and tasted really fresh too.  And i love how they brought the mini dessert rack to show you what they have..that kinda brought out the kiddies side of me seeing all these cute yummy looking dessert glasses....and i just wanted to sample everything!

We had a great dinner experience there.  Cozy decor & great services. We ordered everything from the Fall specials menu.  Love the combinations of the mushrooms, goat cheese, spinach, & truffle oil on the flatbread.  The stuffed quails & organic salmon were cooked perfectly, fresh, & juicy.  We ended up with a pumpkin pie.  Little bit too sweet for me, but my fiancé loved it.

Good ambience, Food portions are too small, I think the menu sais something like every item on the menu is less than 435 calories or something like that. Overall, a classy place to check out if you want to dine in the city.

Actually more like a 4.51 Positives: Really great and upbeat servers, hostess, and bartenders. The piano player is a great touch.  One night we came for dinner and sat back by the kitchen, but they pipe the piano singer throughout the restaurant. Portion sizes solid, especially since they are under 475 calories.  Great for people watching calories. Desserts small and cute in the little shot glasses. Great place to come for late night drink a great piano singer. Much better atmosphere than the often overcrowded Redhead and no cover charge here. Less than positive: Food very good, but not 5-star omg good Wine selection okay Came late other night.  Wanted some bar nosh food to accompany our drinks. Choices, if you don't want flatbread are limited Mushroom flatbread unimpressive

The food was good, not great. I can't remember the last time I saw a more mundane menu. But then again, it matched the room itself. Strip mall generic. All of the employees were happy and helpful but I just can't imagine any reason to visit again. This place will do well with the small town tourist crowd because it is simple, healthy and predictable. Here's a suggestion. At the bottom of the menu they should put this note:  No risks were taken in any of the planning or execution of today's menu.

Had dinner here last Sunday and had a good experience.  I didn't know that the restaurant is a chain, and it certainly didn't feel like it!  Loved that there was a live pianist right in the middle of the bar, and our waitress was super friendly. I had the salmon at the recommendation of our server, which was cooked perfectly, but meh, not super memorable.  (But is salmon ever that great??)  My date had the lamb t-bone chops, which apparently was super tender and the best he'd ever had.  High praise for just a chain restaurant.  Wouldn't mind coming back here, but don't think that I'll make trek up to River North just for that experience.

Had an early dinner on Saturday and it was pretty empty so we were seated promptly. We tried the butternut squash soup and also the steak and onion soup. Bowls were enough to get full! Afterwards I ordered the seared tuna appetizer which was cooked perfectly and tasted fresh! I also tried the pork dish and it was pretty tasty, cooked appropriately over polenta and accompanied with mushrooms and broccolini.  Would I return? Maybe not. With so many unique restaurants in Chicago this is a good staple for healthy American food but I don't know if I would come back again and again.  Service was good but there was also about 4 tables in the entire restaurant so the staff was available.  Ambiance was as expected of a seasons 52 restaurant.
Fabulous food and service.  Reasonably priced and super fresh.  I would definitely come back!

A fourth visit to Seasons 52 and I am even more impressed.  A warm welcome from Brian and the host station staff, great wine, excellent artichoke flat bread, and the salmon entree.  It was even better than it sounds!

I had great experience today for lunch. I am currently on Weight Watchers, and this place is perfect. You can calculate points, all items are under 475 calories. We started with the seafood spring roll and Tamalae Tots. The spring roll was fresh and delicious. Not a fan of the tots, but that is just personal taste. I had the Turkey burger for my entree. So yummy and only 12 WW points. We includged in the Shooter desserts. Fantastic choices, Carrot Cake, Pecan Pie and Chocolate Peanut Butter. Only about 250 calories each, and perfect potion size. Our waiter Jeffrey was great, informative and attentive. I will albsolutely be back!
Solid and healthy menu with great service.   Worth a try!

Here I am again.  Review time.  The bar here is so great, calming actually.  The woodiness, the smells of smokey foods being served combined with the cold outside gives this place a warm/need to drink a real peaty scotch feel.  Ron Swanson would love it here.  Cigars would top it off.  No cigars, but they do have a excellent pianist smack dab in the middle of the bar area. Sitting at the bar you wouldn't know that this was just the 3rd night of Seasons 52's infancy in the Grand/Mag mile area.  They were pouring drinks and chatting up customers like it has been a Chicago local spot for years.  A friendly, and experienced group indeed.  Just a great overall feel to the place.  If your lady, or feminine man needs a foo foo drink, try the superfruit martini.  Its delightful, so my wife says. It was time to move from the bar (my favorite place in a restaurant for a multitude of reasons) to the dining area.  Our server was Carlo who was outstanding, and had a good grasp of the menu ans their specials which fitted fall like a glass slipper on a Disney princess.  Hmmm, I am going to lose my man card with that last comment.  How about fitted fall like a freshly tapped hand fits a boxing glove.  Anyhow, I typically don't go with specials for some reason, but tonight something in the air said be wild.  I unleashed the beast within me, and went for the flappy part of the menu (you know the real narrow piece with the specials on it) and I went special.  We started with the truffled mushroom flatbread which was fantastic, and had the crab/shrimp shrooms as well.  Both were great.  The flatbread was very rustic with its hearty shrooms, a nearly non existent amount of truffle oil (would have liked to taste more) and its roasted garlic chunks.  All in all it was great.  The stuffed shrooms were great as well, and they are served in a cool round thingy that was made for the dish.  They imported them from a small village in the Andes where the villagers make these by hand.  Its a 1000 year old tradition, and is created by very primitive tools/means.  Its amazing.  Underneath the dish you can even see the carvings by the exact villager who created it!  They have one at the Chicago Field Museum that talks all about the process. On to the dinner, and I was totally kidding about the villagers making the dish thing.  I went with the quail special.  It was good.  Gamey, nice glaze, and some tasty risotto.  Oh yeah, there was spinach and some pearl onions on there as well, all equally tasty.  My wife got a salad (I know right?) which she really enjoyed.  It's a salad, and I didn't eat it so I am not gougn  Now the desert part.  Carlo, the devil he is, brought out some serious evil with the little dessert shots.  I went with the pumpkin pie which was off the chain, and my wife got the pecan pie.  Both were outstanding, and really don't make you feel too bad because they are in large shot glasses.  This actually brings me back to something cool that Carlo (that desert slinging monster) said.  All of the dinners at Seasons 52 are 475 cals or less.  Yeah, you can eat a plate of food here that is only 100 cals higher than the pumpkin latte from Starbucks that you gulped down this morning.  Impressive huh.  I thought so. Any new restaurant is not without its flaws and hiccups.  Seasons had some very minor ones, and they are more than apologetic/aware.  At the same time, the restaurant had a 90 minute wait, and was wall to wall packed.  Not sure how high your expectations are, but to run a place effectively as they did without being open for a week is pretty rockstar in my book.  Kudos to the crew that came in from out of the other restaurants to get this one up and running! Good job Seasons 52 glad we visited!

My colleagues and I have been wanting to try the original location in the burbs, but were excited to find out they opened a spot downtown, conveniently near the Grand- Red Line.  Incidentally, we visited on opening night.  My colleague made reservations online easily.  Despite running 20 mins late, we were seated immediately. Our server was super friendly and enthusiastic about the menu.  I couldn't believe all the menu items were under 475 calories.  The cedar-planked roasted salmon with vegetables was delicious.  One friend had the roasted half-chicken and the other friend had the pork tenderloin.  Both dishes were also fantastic. The best part was the dessert sampler.  The server brought a display of the "mini-indulgences" which were the perfect dessert portions.  They had a great variety to offer from chocolate-based to fruit-based.  We each sampled one, the best being the mocha macchiato, followed by the pumpkin pie with the gingersnap crust, then the raspberry chocolate chip cannoli, which was a distant third. Great place to grab a healthy dinner made of fresh ingredients in reasonable portion sizes.
